Fig. 1 Schematic representation of the nanometric structure of different sub-classes of simplified, model catalysts, and technical catalysts. From left to right, the increasing structural complexity and heterogeneity of the materials reduces the level of precision with which their structure can be controlled via synthesis and assessed by characterization methods. Left and right panels were adapted from [117,118], respectively. Fig. 2 (a) Overview (744×721Å2) STM micrograph of MoS2 nanoclusters synthesized on the Au(111) surface at 673K in a sulfidizing atmosphere. (b) Atom-resolved STM micrograph of a single-layer MoS2 crystallite. The presence of sulfur vacancies at the edge of the nanocrystal and the bright rim sites are indicated. (c) Atom-resolved STM micrograph, and the corresponding ball model derived from DFT calculations, of a single-layer CoMoS x nanocrystal supported on Au(111). Adapted from [24,25]. Fig. 3 STM micrographs (upper part) and associated ball models (lower part) of single-layer MoS2 nanocrystals, supported on the Au(111) surface, with varying size and composition. The parameter n denotes the number of Mo atoms on the edge of the clusters. Color code for the ball models: Mo (gray); S (yellow). While clusters with n >6 expose only S-saturated Mo-terminated edges, clusters with n <6 expose preferentially S-terminated edges with different levels of S-coverage. Adapted from [31]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Comparison of the catalytic performance of an industrial HDS catalyst manufactured according to the BRIM™ Haldor Topsøe technology (TK-575 BRIM) and a previous generation of HDS Haldor Topsøe catalysts (TK-573). The plot represents the evolution of the sulfur content in the product stream versus the operation time. The catalytic tests have been performed in a pilot plant using a feed stream consisting of a mixture of a straight run gasoil (SRGO) and a light cycle oil (LCO). Initially, the catalysts were tested under conditions adjusted to get sulfur levels in the product stream in the range of 10–50ppm. During the period of accelerated deactivation, the catalysts were exposed to harsher reaction conditions, to return to the initial reaction conditions in the third period. Reproduced from [33] with permission. Fig. 5 Investigating size effects with 2D model supported catalysts. (a) STM micrograph of Au nanoparticles deposited on a TiO2(110)−(1×1) surface. (b) Evolution of the CO oxidation activity with the Au nanoparticle size. Reaction conditions: CO:O2 =1:5, P =40Torr, T =350K. Activity is expressed as CO2 molecules produced per total Au atom and second. Adapted from [36]. Fig. 6 Atomic-level insight into the dynamics and stability of supported metal single atoms with surface science methods on 2D model catalysts. The figure shows STM micrographs (6.5×8.5nm2, top raw) acquired following deposition of 0.2 monolayer of Pd on the Fe3O4(001) surface at room temperature. The four images are “snapshots” during the exposure of the sample to 5·10−11–5·10−10 mbar of CO (from a to d). The schematic model below each image depicts the observed motion of Pd atoms. Initially (a) only isolated Pd adatoms and OH groups are observed. Between (a) and (b) adatom 1 adsorbs a CO molecule, forming a Pd carbonyl. The Pd carbonyl can diffuse easily on the bare surface, but is immobilized at Pd(2), forming a bright fuzzy feature. From (b) to (d), the Pd carbonyl hops to atom 3 and then to 4, leaving behind its host Pd adatom in each case. Reproduced with permission from [50]. Fig. 7 In situ, high-resolution TEM micrographs (a, c and e) of a Cu/ZnO catalyst in various gas environments together with the corresponding Wulff constructions of the Cu nanocrystals (b, d and f). (a) 1.5mbar of H2 at 493K. (c) Gas mixture of H2 and H2O, H2:H2O=3:1 at a total pressure of 1.5mbar at 493K. (e) Gas mixture of H2 (95%) and CO (5%) at a total pressure of 5mbar at 493K. Reproduced with permission from [66]. Fig. 8 Time-lapsed, in situ bright-field TEM micrographs of Ni nanoparticles on a low-surface-area MgAl2O4 support heated at 750°C in a 1:1 H2/H2O gas mixture (total pressure of 360–400Pa). The scale bars correspond to 5nm in panel a and 20nm in panel b. In panel a, the red circle indicates a small Ni nanoparticle which shrinks due to emission of metal atoms (to eventually disappear). In panel b, the sequence of snapshot images shows the diffusion of four labeled Ni nanoparticles on the support surface and their coalescence with neighboring, smaller Ni nanoparticles. Arrows show the particle mobility seen in each next frame. Reproduced with permission from [48]. Fig. 9 Representative TEM micrograph of an industrial catalyst manufactured according to the FENCE™ Haldor Topsøe technology. Metal nanoparticles (darker objects) are surrounded, and kept apart, by a “fence” of oxide nanocrystals. Reproduced with permission from Haldor Topsøe A/S. Fig. 10 Understanding the impact of the spatial distribution of supported metal nanoparticles with 3D model catalysts. (a–d) Tomographic cross sections showing the interior structure of CuZn/SBA-15 model catalysts with the Cu nanoparticles (black objects) clustered in only few of the 1D pores of the silica support material (a and b) or evenly distributed all over the support porosity, with near-maximum interparticle distances (c and d). (e) Evolution of the normalized methanol productivity with the time-on-stream for CuZn/SBA-15 catalysts with near-maximum (top, CuZn/S(N2)) or very short (bottom, CuZn/S(NO)) Cu interparticle distances. Reaction conditions: synthesis gas feedstock 7% CO2:23% CO:60% H2:10% Ar (internal standard), T =533K, P =40bar, gas hourly space velocity of 2–3lg−1 h−1, initial conversion (CO+CO2)=(15–20%). Adapted from [101]. Fig. 11 3D model catalysts based on morphologically tailored oxide supports. The figure shows bright-field TEM micrographs of 1%Au/CeO2 prepared by deposition–precipitation of gold from an aqueous solution of HAuCl4 onto CeO2 nanocrystals with rod (a), cube, (b) and polyhedral (c) crystal morphology. The insets show schematic representations of the CeO2 crystals and the corresponding surface-exposed facets. At that time, catalyst development and optimization strongly relied on phenomenological approaches and experimental know-how, whereas little knowledge existed on the nature of the catalytically active species and how to tune their structure and concentration. For more than 70years, Topsøe has advocated the need of “bringing more scientific understanding to the field of catalysis,” becoming a prominent figure in the transition of catalyst preparation – a word with an alchemical connotation – to catalyst synthesis, based on scientific principles. Numerous fundamental studies of his team and collaborators on simplified model catalysts have added substantially to the current understanding of a significant number of industrially relevant systems in particular, and the principles of action of solid catalysts in general. This article reviews some key advancements that the Topsøe team has contributed to the field of catalyst development, rooted in fundamental studies with either 2D or 3D model materials. Examples are provided of how the acquired scientific knowledge was successfully translated into innovations in the manufacture of technical catalysts. Next to the work of the Topsøe group, a broader and updated perspective of the use of model systems to investigate fundamental aspects of catalyst development is presented. A number of selected case studies are reviewed, which we find illustrative of recent findings with implications for the design and synthesis of solid catalysts. Keywords Catalyst synthesis Model catalysts Surface science Scanning electron microscopy Environmental TEM Fundamental studies Structure sensitivity 0 Introduction The 1930s were a period when a number of technological innovations in the use of solid catalysts entered industrial application. In 1936, a thermal-cracking unit was revamped in Paulsboro (USA) to operate the Houdry catalytic cracking process using the natural clay Fuller’s Earth as solid acid catalyst [1]. Almost at the same time the first Fischer–Tropsch synthesis plant was deployed by Ruhr-Chemie in Oberhausen (Germany), applying a Co–ThO2–MgO catalyst supported on diatomaceous earth to produce over 60,000t/a of synthetic liquid fuels [2]. Soon after, Union Carbide put on line the first ethylene epoxidation unit based on a silver catalyst in Clendenin (USA) [3]. In 1936, Haldor Topsøe graduated in physics and chemical engineering at the Technical University of Denmark. This combination of fundamental and applied training was further complemented with 4-year experience as a process engineer in industry, which shaped his interest in catalysis, a discipline with the potential to bridge basic science with practical application. As the German occupation of Denmark began in 1940, Topsøe’s expectations of finding a position in academia vanished and he decided to start his own company. Haldor Topsøe A/S was set up to develop and commercialize solid catalysts and processes for the chemical industry. Topsøe saw in the burgeoning technological relevance of catalysis the source of economic viability to both justify and finance his passion for fundamental science. As he often remarked, the foremost goal was to “bring more science into the field of industrial catalysts” [4]. Nowadays, ca. 85% of all the existing chemical processes rely on the use of catalysts, 80% of which are solid catalysts [5]. The ever-growing world catalyst market amounts currently to ca. 20billionUS$/a, with the overall economic impact of the processes in which these catalysts are applied being ca. two orders of magnitude higher. Since its foundation in 1940, the Haldor Topsøe company has become a major pacesetter in the catalyst industry. It currently develops a broad portfolio of solid catalysts, with emphasis on refinery, petrochemistry, and environmental protection. Along its 75years of history, the company has followed the pathway initially delineated by its founder. Topsøe assembled a team of talented scientists and engineers and a network of extramural academic collaborators, which he infected with his enthusiasm for technical developments based on fundamental understanding. For several decades, the Topsøe team has contributed decisively to supplement empiricism in catalyst development with scientific insight, paving the transition of the discipline from an “art” into a science. Under relevant operation conditions, the performance of solid catalysts is by and large determined by their genesis. Synthesis and activation/conditioning procedures are often highly influential on key structural features directly linked to the ultimate catalytic behavior, that is, activity, selectivity, and stability [6,7]. It is hence appropriate to consider catalyst design and synthesis within the most consequential steps of any industrial process. At the time Haldor Topsøe founded his company, catalyst manufacture and optimization was achieved via rather phenomenological approaches. Preparation recipes included high-temperature co-annealing of ground oxides or contacting solutions or suspensions of metal (oxide) precursors with porous support materials, namely consisting of naturally occurring minerals with rather heterogeneous structural properties. The catalytic performance of the resulting materials, often vaguely referred to as “active masses”, relied strongly not only on their composition but also on preparation “know-how” held by the experienced manufacturers, whereas limited knowledge existed on the nature of the active species and how to deliberately maximize their occurrence. Haldor Topsøe and his team are a prime example of a group of prominent scientists who have advocated resolutely what has been coined the “reductionism approach” in catalysis research – and they have demonstrated the benefits of this approach. Diverging from phenomenological strategies, the main aim is to study simplified model systems in which the complexity of technical catalysts is “deconvoluted” so that different fundamental aspects can be investigated systematically. Ideally, the basic understanding generated with model systems helps in the development of guidelines for the rational design and synthesis of advanced technical catalysts. In this contribution, we review some key advancements that Haldor Topsøe and his collaborators have contributed to the field of catalyst development, rooted in fundamental studies with model systems. We first describe the principles and tools pertaining to different classes of model catalysts. Then, relevant case studies from the work of the Topsøe team are discussed, with examples of how the scientific insight was successfully translated into advanced technical catalysts. In addition, we review a number of selected studies by different research groups, which we find illustrative of recent findings with implications for the design and synthesis of solid catalysts, and which also rely on the application of simplified model systems. Rather than a comprehensive review, the aim is to provide selected snapshots to convey an idea of which fundamental aspects are being intensively investigated as well as which approaches are currently pursued to bridge the “gaps” between model and technical catalysts. 1 Model catalysts By definition, model catalysts possess precisely defined and more homogeneous structural features than their industrially relevant counterparts, which typically display a significant degree of complexity and heterogeneity at the atomic, nano- and even micro-meter length scales. For the purpose of this discussion, we will group them into two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) model catalysts. Fig. 1 depicts schematically the prototypical configurations of the two classes of model systems in relation to the less well-defined structure typical of technical catalysts. The dimensionality of model catalysts is intimately linked to the battery of physico-chemical methods which can be applied, and the range of conditions under which the materials can be studied, which in turn determine those scientific aspects of catalyst synthesis and functionality which can be investigated. 1.1 Two-dimensional model catalysts Two-dimensional model catalysts comprise an extended flat surface, either a single-crystal or polycrystalline, or an amorphous thin film deposited on a substrate. When the goal is to mimic supported metal catalysts, metal nanoclusters or nanoparticles are additionally deposited on the planar support [8–10]. Their geometry makes them suitable to be studied with a large number of surface science techniques. The surface science approach in the field of catalysis dates back to the gas adsorption studies of Langmuir in the early 20th century [11]. Particularly since the 1960s, a wealth of techniques have been developed which deliver precise information on the composition, topology, and reactivity of solid surfaces with down to atomic resolution [12]. These include surface spectroscopic methods, such as X-ray photoelectron (XPS), Auger (AES), electron energy-loss (EELS), or reflection adsorption infrared (RAIRS) spectroscopies. If the signal is weak, often grazing incidence geometries are employed in order to maximize the interaction of the probe beam with the structures to be studied. Also widely used are temperature-resolved techniques, such as temperature programmed desorption or reaction, and surface microscopy methods, such as scanning-tunneling (STM) and atomic-force (AFM) microscopies which, at the current state of development, enable element-specific, atomic level imaging of the investigated surfaces. This set of surface science methods have contributed decisively to the maturation of catalysis as a scientific discipline, as recognized with the Nobel prize awarded to Gerhard Ertl in 2007 [13]. Often detailed information on the chemical composition, element speciation, and topology of the surface of 2D model systems can be obtained after several treatment steps, designed to mimic catalyst synthesis, conditioning, or usage. The (dynamic) interaction of the solid surface with adsorbed molecules can also be monitored in situ, with atomic precision, to gain insight into reaction mechanisms, the nature of active sites, or the reasons underlying catalyst deactivation phenomena. Moreover, the atomic-scale information obtained with surface science methods on planar model systems represents often the best experimental complement for quantum-mechanic simulations [14]. However, a number of limitations are inherent to 2D model systems in catalysis. First, common synthesis methods which can be used in surface science, for example, cleaving of single crystals, sputtering, chemical vapor deposition, spin coating, deposition of pre-synthesized colloids, electron beam lithography, etc. differ fundamentally from the preparation methodologies applied to produce industrially relevant catalysts. The latter typically involve metal precursors in solution, which are either applied on a porous carrier, for example, impregnation, ion exchange, or from which a solid phase is segregated and isolated, for example, crystallization, precipitation. To overcome such “synthesis gap,” scientific efforts have been committed to combine flat substrates with wet-chemistry synthesis strategies, as recently reviewed in a perspective article by Sterrer and Freund [15]. Second, the structure of 2D model catalysts at supra-atomic length scales is very different from that of most technologically relevant catalysts, which are porous and bear a higher density and diversity of surface defects. This is generally referred to as the “materials gap” between simplified 2D systems and technical catalysts [16]. In addition, the range of experimental settings at which most surface science methods operate, generally under clean, well-controlled, often ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) conditions, are distinctly different from those typically encountered in industrial practice. In this respect, significant progress has also been achieved over the last two decades in bridging this “pressure gap” with the development of in situ surface techniques which operate under near-ambient pressures, and the successful integration of UHV analysis chambers with attached high-pressure compartments allowing quasi-in situ gas phase reactions to be carried out [17,18]. Nonetheless, central aspects such as the absence of capillary effects in non-porous substrates and significant differences in the gas–solid hydrodynamics with respect to what is customary for industrial catalytic processes still represent significant barriers between flat model catalysts and their technologically relevant counterparts. 1.2 Three-dimensional model catalysts A second class of model systems, herein denoted as three-dimensional model catalysts, has proved instrumental in bridging both the “synthesis” and “materials” gaps to the technical catalysts. They are porous and constituted by primary particles whose structure extends in the three directions in space. Often, these model systems consist of catalytic metal species (nanoclusters or nanoparticles) deposited within the pores of a support. In other cases, the primary particles of the support material are deliberately non-porous, that is, the catalyst porosity corresponds to the void spaces between the carrier particles, to prevent confinement of the supported metal species, as desired when the goal is their visualization with high-resolution electron microscopy methods. Unlike their 2D counterparts, the porous nature of the 3D model catalysts enables systematic investigations of several phenomena of relevance for catalyst synthesis and usage, namely the role of the support porosity and related capillary effects, mass transport, and confinement effects. In most cases, preparation involves, at least partially, industrially relevant methodologies, for example, impregnation, deposition–precipitation, hydrothermal crystallization, etc. even though a higher degree of complexity in the synthesis and assembly procedures is often assumed in exchange of an advanced control over key structural features at the nano- and meso-scales. Examples are the employment of soft- or hard-templating strategies to synthesize support materials with tunable and regular porosities [19,20], or the use of colloidal methods to achieve highly monodispersed and compositionally homogeneous supported metal phases [21]. Given their closer structural resemblance with technical materials, the array of physico-chemical methods applied to study 3D model catalysts, for example, sorption, spectroscopy, and microscopy techniques, corresponds essentially to those employed to investigate their industrially relevant analogs. However, the fine-tuned, regular features of the model systems generally facilitate interpretation and modeling of the characterization results, maximizing the insight at a fundamental level. Furthermore, as they are obtained in the form of powders, these model catalysts can be shaped into macroscopic pellets, allowing them to be exposed to industrially relevant reaction conditions, not only as it regards temperature, pressure, and composition of their environment, but also reproducing the gas–solid or liquid–solid hydrodynamics encountered in industrial operations. Over several decades, basic studies on simplified 2D and 3D model catalysts have been a prominent workhorse of the Topsøe team in the process of designing and optimizing synthesis routes toward more active, selective, and/or durable industrial solid catalysts in a wide array of applications. In the following, selected showcases are discussed, with indications of how the fundamental knowledge acquired with model systems was translated into innovations at the level of industrial catalysts. In addition, selected recent literature examples of the application of model catalysts to improve our understanding of catalyst synthesis, and its consequences for the ultimate catalyst performance, are briefly reviewed. 2 2D model catalysts and surface science methods in catalysis 2.1 2D model systems at Haldor Topsøe: development of hydrodesulfurization catalysts Topsøe researchers have long cooperated, particularly with the Besenbacher group (Aarhus University), on the application of surface science methods, namely scanning-tunneling-microscopy (STM), to study model catalysts. One of the earliest studies reported the application of STM to investigate the surface topology of a flat slab, cutoff from a commercial Fe ammonia synthesis catalyst [22]. Later, the method was advanced and applied to other catalytic systems, with the collection of studies on molybdenum sulfide-based hydrotreating catalysts probably being the most prominent example. Catalysts based on MoS2, doped with Co or Ni heteroatoms, often supported on porous Al2O3 carriers, have been long applied as hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalysts to reduce the sulfur content of hydrocarbon feedstocks in the refining industry [23]. Since the 1990s, ever-increasingly stringent legislations which limit the sulfur content in transportation fuels, particularly Diesel fuel, together with the need to process lower-quality, sulfur-rich oil feedstocks to meet the worldwide fuel demand, placed a heavy burden on the hydrotreating processes and called for breakthroughs in the development of HDS catalysts toward improved activity and compatibility with heavy feedstocks. Extensive research efforts in the 1970s and 1980s led to the proposal of two main reaction mechanisms for the conversion of sulfur-bearing organic compounds, that is, the direct desulfurization route and the pre-hydrogenation pathway [23]. Structural characterization additionally pointed to the preferential location of Co and Ni dopants at the edges of MoS2-like nanocrystallites, and linked the HDS activity to the presence of sulfur vacancies associated with those crystallite edges [23]. It was also revealed that a strong interaction of the (Co,Ni)MoS2 crystallites with the support material resulted in less active (type I) sites, whereas minimizing the number of linkages to the support, via either the use of weakly interacting supports, or the application of chelating agents during catalyst preparation, or high temperature sulfidation pre-treatments, maximized the proportion of the most active (type II) sites. Since the late 1990s, researchers at Haldor Topsøe and coworkers at Aarhus University took significant steps forward in the establishment of structure–performance relationships for MoS2-based HDS catalysts based on atomic-level studies of 2D model catalysts. Helveg et al. prepared small MoS2 crystallites on an inert Au(111) substrate via e-beam evaporation of molybdenum followed by a sulfurization treatment with H2S [24]. Later, the synthesis procedure was also extended to supported crystallites bearing Co and Ni dopant atoms [25]. These 2D model catalysts were thoroughly investigated with STM (Fig. 2 ). The metal sulfide crystallites showed a single-layer structure with basal shapes ranging from triangular for unpromoted MoS2 to (truncated) triangular and hexagonal for Ni- and Co-doped clusters. Given that atom-resolved STM micrographs can be regarded as an atomic-level map of the local density of states, density functional theory (DFT) simulations were further employed to interpret the surface microscopy results. This analysis revealed the preferential location of Ni and Co dopants at the edges of the crystallites, which confirmed earlier hypothesis [26]. However, a strong preference was found for a very specific type of perimeter sites, that is, those corresponding to the sulfur-terminated edges in the hypothetical unpromoted crystallites. At these edges, atomic protrusions were also imaged, which corresponded to sulfur vacancies such as those previously proposed to constitute the most active, type II HDS sites. In addition, a pronounced, bright rim was observed all around the crystallites, at a single-atom distance from the edges. Such “brim sites,” as defined by the authors, occurred equally in unpromoted and Co- or Ni-doped nanocrystals. Their higher intensity in STM micrographs is, according to DFT modeling, an indication of a pronounced metallic character, in contrast to the known overall semiconductor nature of the MoS2 crystallites [27]. In subsequent studies, STM imaging was coupled in situ to the dosage of selected molecules [28]. This enabled monitoring the interaction of adsorbed species with the different types of sites previously identified on the bare crystallites, and shed light on possible HDS active sites and reaction mechanisms. On the one hand, direct desulfurization routes seemed to occur on sulfur vacancies associated with the edge sites, which were shown to become poisoned by H2S. On the other hand, the metallic-like brim sites were found to play a decisive role in hydrogenation pathways. Hydrogenation-assisted desulfurization reactions were concluded to occur via activation of sulfur-containing reactants at the brim sites, followed by migration of H adatoms from the neighboring edge sites. In addition, the brim sites were not inhibited by H2S adsorption, whereas they were poisoned by nitrogen-bearing compounds. This set of observations helped link a high number of experimental facts, from extensive reactive studies to molecular processes and intrinsic structural features of the catalysts at the atomic scale [29]. Besides the intrinsic properties of the active species, the selection of the support material is of central relevance for the design of supported catalysts, as it determines the nature and strength of the physico-chemical interactions which might be established between the carrier and the dispersed phases. Often, the nature of the support is primarily dictated by operational considerations, such as its chemical and mechanical stability under the process conditions. The dispersion of the supported metal species and the degree of interaction with the surface of the support material can be controlled, to some extent, via careful selection of the metal precursors, the experimental conditions, and the use of additives during the metal incorporation steps, or the conditions for the thermal treatments often required to activate the catalyst. Investigations conducted by the Topsøe team and coworkers [30] on model MoS2 nanocrystals supported on a graphene substrate, displaying surface defects deliberately created by ion-bombardment, provided some insights into the nature of the active phase–support interactions. Graphite is more representative for realistic carriers than gold, though it is certainly a weakly interacting support material as compared to the industrially relevant Al2O3. When imaged with STM, the MoS2 crystallites showed the characteristic bright brim, indicative that this is an inherent feature of the metal sulfide crystallites. In addition, it was possible to pinpoint the anchoring sites of the MoS2 nanocrystals to the carbon support. The authors concluded that linkages to the support involved predominantly sites located at the edges of the supported crystallites, where the crystalline order was perturbed, while bonding through the basal plane was deemed weak. These results provided atomic-level evidence for the detrimental nature of the chemical linkages to the support material for the full development of the type II HDS sites, associated with the edges of the (doped) MoS2 crystallites. Another central design parameter of supported catalysts is the size of the dispersed nanoclusters or nanoparticles. The model MoS2 crystallites supported on a Au(111) surface provided a suitable model system to also investigate intrinsic size effects. To this end, Lauritsen et al. [31] synthesized MoS2 nanocrystals of various sizes on a gold substrate. The single-layer nanocrystals displayed triangular shapes, with 4–14 molybdenum atoms along the edge, corresponding to equivalent basal diameters in the range of 1.5–4nm (Fig. 3 ). STM imaging confirmed the presence of the bright brim, irrespective of the cluster size. Most strikingly, it was found that clusters with less than 6 Mo atoms along the edge showed a higher propensity to expose the so-called S-terminated edges, with a higher proportion of sulfur vacancies, whereas larger crystallites exposed preferentially S-saturated Mo-terminated edges. As the so-called type II sites, responsible for direct desulfurization catalytic steps, are likely to be associated only with the first family of edges, these observations suggested that an optimal MoS2 crystallite size of ca. 1.5–2.2nm would maximize the occurrence of this important class of active sites. Based on the basic knowledge obtained from the discussed studies on model 2D catalysts, the Haldor Topsøe company developed the BRIM™ proprietary technology to manufacture industrial hydrotreating catalysts [32]. It is claimed that synthesis parameters and conditioning treatments can be designed to tune the relative abundance of different classes of reaction sites in the active (Co,Ni)MoS2 species, as desired for different specific operations. Direct desulfurization reaction pathways are favored by maximizing the abundance of type II, edge-related, active sites. Alternatively, hydrogenation mechanisms can be boosted when synthesis conditions are directed toward the maximum occurrence of brim-type sites. Due to the different susceptibility of the various kinds of active sites to inhibition by H2S or nitrogen-containing compounds, the same strategies might serve to adjust the vulnerability of the catalyst to either high sulfidating operation conditions or the presence of poisoning compounds in different feedstocks. When exposed to industrially relevant hydrodesulfurization conditions and accelerated deactivation cycles, for example, contact with heavy feeds, high operation temperatures and low H2 availability, catalysts developed with the BRIM™ technology displayed higher initial activity alongside improved resistance to deactivation as compared to previous generations of Topsøe hydrotreating materials (Fig. 4 ) [33]. The BRIM catalyst portfolio includes materials specifically designed for various feedstocks and processes, including ultra-low sulfur Diesel production and pretreatment of fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) or hydrocraking feed-streams. These innovations underscore the relevance of fundamental studies on simplified, 2D model catalysts as a means to set firm scientific grounds for the rational development of industrial catalysts. 2.2 Recent examples of the use of 2D model systems to guide catalyst design and synthesis Surface science studies on planar model catalysts have proved highly valuable to guide catalyst design for a wide range of processes. Given the ubiquitous manifestation of structure sensitivity in catalysis [34], an important design variable for supported catalysts is the size of the supported metal species. Gold-based catalysts represent a remarkable example. Already the earliest studies reporting on the catalytic properties of supported Au nanoparticles recognized a strong dependence of activity on the metal nanoparticle size [35]. Working with nearly monodispersed, planar Au/TiO2 model catalysts, Goodman and coworkers [36] identified a rather narrow optimal Au nanoparticle size range, around 2–3nm, which showed maximum catalytic activity in the oxidation of CO, as a relevant test reaction (Fig. 5 ). Research on the electronic structure of differently sized Au clusters by surface-tunneling-spectroscopy led them to propose that such remarkable structure sensitivity was due to quantum size effects. The most active particles showed electronic band-gaps intermediate between those of larger crystallites, which displayed a classical metallic behavior, and those of smaller clusters, which adopted a single-layer morphology. More recently, investigations on nanoparticle size effects using 2D model catalysts have been extended to a large number of catalytic reactions including selective hydrogenation [37], oxidation [38], and the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [39,40] to cite some. The gained insight serves to design synthesis and activation protocols for industrial catalysts geared at maximizing the occurrence of metal nanoparticles with an optimal size. The atomic resolution provided by some microscopic and spectroscopic surface science methods allows investigating size effects down to the sub-nanometer range, extending to the limit of single-atom catalysts. A number of recent studies illustrate the power of this approach, often in concert with quantum–mechanical simulations, to reveal the singular physico-chemical properties of single metal atoms isolated within a matrix of either a different metal or an oxide [41,42]. Such atomic-scale insights are expected to be highly valuable to increase our current understanding of promoter and site-isolation effects in catalysis, as well as to develop a deeper rationale of the action principles of single-atom metal catalysts, of whose exotic, in cases highly advantageous, catalytic properties there is a growing number of experimental evidences [43–46]. Nonetheless, a major limitation envisaged for single-atom catalysts relates to their long-term stability under reactive conditions. Metal atoms are inherently prone to coalesce into clusters and grow into larger agglomerates to reduce their surface energy. Agglomeration and growth is a prominent cause of deactivation for metal catalysts, and it might proceed via either direct migration and coalescence of metal clusters, or Ostwald ripening (atom exchange) mechanisms [47,48]. Also here, surface science studies on planar model systems can shed light into the underlying mechanisms and suggest feasible strategies to mitigate metal agglomeration. Farmer and Campbell [49] found the nature of the oxide support material to be highly influential for the stability of Ag clusters deposited on flat substrates, and ascribed this observation to local metal–oxide bonding and strain effects. More recently, Parkinson et al. [50] imaged the surface migration and agglomeration behavior of Pd atoms sputtered on a Fe3O4(001) surface (Fig. 6 ). Time-lapsed STM tracking of single metal atoms revealed the critical role of palladium carbonyl species, formed upon dosing CO to the system, to initiate atom mobility and agglomeration. Their observations underscore the prime role of adsorbates as “courier” of metal atoms in solid-state Ostwald ripening processes. Moreover, certain hydroxylated surface sites of the oxide support were found to stabilize Pd atoms against carbonyl formation and surface diffusion, suggesting that such basic studies on simplified systems might help delineate a blueprint to design stable single-atom catalysts. A permanent goal in the field of catalysis is to bring preparation methodologies for model systems as close as possible to those of relevance in the manufacture of industrial catalysts. This represents a challenge particularly in the case of 2D model catalysts. In this respect, a number of research groups have recently demonstrated how synthesis methodologies involving deposition of metal precursors from a liquid phase on an oxide surface, therefore relevant for industrial preparation procedures such as impregnation, ion adsorption or deposition–precipitation, can be applied on planar substrates to synthesize 2D model catalysts. In addition, surface science analytical techniques have progressed to the point that they can be applied in situ to probe the liquid–solid interface, thereby providing relevant insight into the elementary steps involved during catalyst synthesis. Park et al. [51] used resonant anomalous X-ray reflectivity to investigate the structure of Pt(NH3)4 2+ ions when adsorbed from an aqueous solution of Pt(NH3)4Cl2 onto a quartz monocrystal, a process which is of relevance for the preparation of Pt/SiO2 catalysts via ion adsorption. More recently, Carrier and coworkers [52] took a step forward by investigating the precipitation of α-Ni(OH)2 species from an aqueous solution on different facets of an α-Al2O3 substrate with in situ, polarization dependent, grazing-incidence X-ray absorption spectroscopy. Their experiments revealed a significant surface structure dependence of the metal deposition process. While the Al2O3(0001) facet showed no significant Ni uptake, deposition of nickel hydroxide species took place predominantly on monocrystals exposing the (1−102) facet. These results therefore suggest that morphological control over the α-Al2O3 support crystals, to preferentially expose selected facets on the surface, might be useful as an efficient approach to maximize metal loading in Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by deposition–precipitation, which are relevant for hydrogenation and reforming processes. Model catalysts deposited on planar substrates from precursors in solution have also been applied to investigate the structural and chemical modifications brought about by subsequent thermal treatments which mimic calcination/reduction [53] or sulfidation [54] procedures typically applied to set industrial catalysts to their active state. Advances in surface science methods to probe processes at the solid–liquid interface have not been restricted to spectroscopy but also concern surface imaging techniques. An illustrative example is the development of in situ AFM cells, which have been lately applied to monitor growth processes during the crystallization of zeolites [55,56] and related crystalline microporous materials from precursor solutions [57]. Zeolites, and more generally zeotype materials, are ubiquitous in industrial catalytic processes [5,58] and play also an important role in related separation operations [59,60]. The new information on the crystallization mechanisms acquired on 2D model systems is anticipated to be valuable in devising strategies to control the crystal size and/or aspect-ratio of these materials, which are morphological parameters of the greatest significance for their performance as catalysts [61]. 3 3D model catalysts 3.1 3D model systems at Haldor Topsøe: dynamic response and deactivation of supported metal nanoparticles Given their closer structural resemblance to industrially relevant analogs, powdered model supported catalysts have been extensively applied by Topsøe researchers in complementary investigations to assist the development and optimization of technical catalysts. This has been particularly relevant in connection with the development and application of in situ (or environmental) transmission electron microscopy (TEM) facilities. Soon after the first report on the application of high-resolution TEM to image solids in a gas environment, at elevated temperatures [62], Haldor Topsøe recognized the high potential of this method to deliver insight into important aspects of “working” solid catalysts and commenced to set up an in-house, in situ TEM microscope. Since then, imaging of supported metal catalysts during their high-temperature exposure to reactive atmospheres (in the mbar pressure range) has provided unprecedented insights into phenomena such as the dynamic nature of catalytic metal nanoparticles and the mechanisms involved in particle growth and catalyst deactivation. Owing to the highly porous and irregular nanostructure typical of most industrial catalysts, in situ TEM experiments are often facilitated by the design of alternative model catalysts. In particular, low surface area, non-porous oxides are preferred as support materials, and the catalytic metal nanoparticles are deposited on their external surface. This prevents pore-confinement of the metal nanoparticles and enables their imaging at the edges of the support primary particles, with minimum overlapping from other metal particles or features of the support material in the same projection plane. On the other hand, this oversimplifies the situation with respect to particle movement and agglomeration, since the pronounced pore system of many technical catalysts also serves to maintain high dispersion for longer periods of time. Such limitations should always be kept in mind when interpreting data obtained with model systems. Particularly noteworthy have been the in situ TEM investigations conducted at Haldor Topsøe A/S on methanol synthesis catalysts. With a worldwide demand of ca. 70millionton/a, methanol is a key feedstock for the production of essential platform chemicals, such as formaldehyde, acetic acid or short-chain olefins, and a promising candidate fuel in combustion engines or fuel cells [63]. Industrial methanol synthesis catalysts typically consist of a high loading (50–70wt%) of Cu, as 5–10nm nanoparticles, dispersed within a complex matrix of ZnO and Al2O3 nanocrystals [64]. As model catalysts, researchers at Haldor Topsøe investigated materials incorporating low amounts of Cu dispersed as nanoparticles on the external surface of low-surface-area carriers such as flame-synthesized ZnO crystals or Stöber SiO2 spheres [65]. In one such study, Hansen et al. [66] revealed, with atomic resolution, the dynamic and reversible shape changes undergone by supported Cu nanoparticles, at the reaction temperature, in response to changes in the gas atmosphere composition. As depicted in Fig. 7 , Cu nanocrystals were shown to be “flexible” entities under reaction conditions, acquiring rounder shapes, with low contact angles with the support, under more oxidizing environments, and flattening against the support surface under more reducing atmospheres. Such dynamic particle reshaping was ascribed to the interplay between surface reconstructions of the Cu crystallites induced by certain adsorbates, particularly H2O, and the redox state of the support surface, which in the case of ZnO depends on the oxidation potential of the gas atmosphere. The existence of reversible changes in the structure and catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO methanol synthesis catalysts, as a function of the gas composition, had been proposed earlier on the basis of in situ spectroscopic studies [67,68]. However, direct visualization of such dynamic nanocrystal rearrangements with environmental TEM provided a direct confirmation of the involvement of wetting/non-wetting phenomena and enabled identifying the facets predominantly exposed on the surface of the Cu nanocrystals, and therefore available for catalysis, under different gas atmospheres. This landmark study by the Haldor Topsøe team contributed crucially to the development of the notion that supported metal nanoparticles are rather dynamic objects during their catalytic action, and helped to explain the different catalytic behavior exhibited by similarly sized Cu nanoparticles when supported on different oxide carriers. A phenomenon which is also profoundly related to the dynamic character of metallic nanocrystals under reaction conditions is particle growth. As mentioned before, particle growth, or sintering, is considered to proceed via two main mechanisms. The first is the diffusive surface migration of metal clusters or nanoparticles, and their coalescence upon collision – often termed as migration and coalescence. In contrast, growth may also occur by exchange of monoatomic metal species between static nanoparticles, driven by differences in particle size, and thereby in surface energy – often referred to as Ostwald ripening, after the process described by Ostwald in liquid phase [69]. The decrease in metal surface area caused by particle growth is a prominent reason for deactivation of several industrial catalysts, which becomes highly problematical when the intrinsic catalytic properties depend strongly on the metal particle size. Phenomenologically, the onset of surface and bulk atom mobility in metal crystallites has been linked to the so-called Hüttig and Tamman temperatures, which are defined as ca. 1/3 and 1/2 of the melting point, respectively [70]. These parameters, however, do not take into account possible effects of adsorbates, which might play an important role in the mobility of atoms on the surface of metal nanocrystals. Therefore, direct catalyst monitoring with environmental TEM provides a more realistic view of the metal dynamics and the associated particle growth mechanisms during the operation of metal catalysts. Stable performance and extended lifetime are critical parameters of industrial catalysts. Topsøe researchers, as well as extramural collaborators, have devoted substantial efforts to improve the understanding of metal catalyst sintering by investigating 3D model catalysts under reactive environments in their in situ TEM facilities [48,71,72]. As illustrated in Fig. 8 , from the work of Hansen et al. [48], for the case of Ni nanoparticles supported on a low-surface-area MgAl2O4 support, under conditions mimicking a steam reforming process, both shrinkage and disappearance of static Ni nanoparticles, indicative of an Ostwald ripening process, and migration and coalescence of Ni particles in close neighborhood to each other could be unambiguously imaged. These studies on model systems were complemented with reactive and aging tests with technical catalysts based on porous support materials [73]. This approach helped researchers rationalize the relative contribution of the two growth mechanisms as a function of the initial catalyst structure, for example, metal particle size distribution, and under different operation conditions. The acquired mechanistic knowledge has direct implications for the design of industrial catalysts more resistant to deactivation by sintering. Whereas a narrow metal particle size distribution might be targeted to counteract an Ostwald ripening mechanism, by minimizing the net thermodynamic driving force for growth, more emphasis may be laid on the spatial distribution of the metal particles and the structure of the support material if the aim is to impede particle migration and coalescence. The scientific understanding gained on the dynamic behavior and deactivation pathways of supported metal nanoparticles represents the grounds for the FENCE™ synthesis technology, trademarked by Haldor Topsøe A/S. The nanoscale structure of catalysts manufactured with this technology consists of metal nanoparticles surrounded by a “picket fence” of multiple metal oxide crystallites, as it is illustrated in the transmission electron micrograph shown in Fig. 9 . The corona of oxide nanocrystals is claimed to play the dual role of support and sintering barrier. Whereas it provides sufficient access to the catalytic metal surface, it additionally helps keep the individual metal nanoparticles apart. This might contribute to hinder metal particle coalescence and extend catalyst lifetime. The FENCE™ materials portfolio includes Cu-based catalysts for methanol synthesis and the low-temperature water–gas shift reaction, processes in which the growth of the catalytic Cu nanoparticles represents a prominent deactivation pathway. This exemplifies how industrial-scale catalyst manufacture can profit from the scientific understanding generated from basic investigations on 3D model catalysts. 3.2 Recent examples for the use of 3D model systems to guide catalyst design and synthesis In the last two decades, significant advancements in the controlled synthesis and assembly of nanostructures have widened the scope of materials which have served as well-defined models to investigate fundamental aspects of solid catalysts. Model supported catalysts have been particularly instrumental in addressing metal particle size effects for a large number of reactions. To this end, materials synthesis routes are designed to achieve the highest possible control over the metal particle size. In the sub-nanometer range, metal nanoclusters of selected sizes can be obtained, with atomic precision, via decomposition of organometallic precursors on the surface of oxide supports [74]. In the most widely studied 1–10nm range, size control often implies the synthesis of metal nanoparticles “ex ante”, typically using colloidal methods. Subsequently, the pre-synthesized metal colloids are incorporated either on the external surface [75] or inside the pores of a suitable support material [76]. An alternative approach involves the growth of the porous support material around the metal colloids [77,78]. In certain cases, however, metal particles synthesized via colloidal routes, particularly in aqueous media, are considerably larger than those typically of interest for most catalytic applications, often <10nm. In these cases, ex post metal leaching reactions have been proposed to controllably reduce the metal particle size into the range of interest [79]. In addition, the nature of the support material needs also to be judiciously selected when the aim is to investigate intrinsic particle size effects. In particular for transition metal catalysts, this often requires preventing the reaction of very small metal nanoparticles with the surface of the carrier material, which might result in the formation of metal-support mixed compounds and masking of the “true” particle size catalytic effects. Some studies have successfully circumvented this limitation by using weakly interacting materials, such as low-surface area [80] or surface-functionalized oxides [81], and carbon nanostructures [82,83] as supports for model catalysts. In addition to metal particle size, the spatial distribution of the metal nanoparticles within the porous structure of the support material might have catalytic consequences. At a micrometer length scale, catalyst bodies with non-uniform, core–shell, or egg-yolk metal distributions are deliberately designed to counteract diffusion limitations or to protect the metal catalyst from a poison in the feed, respectively [5,84]. At the nanoscale, non-uniform distributions, with significant clustering of metal species in high-metal-density domains, have been reported for various industrial catalysts [85,86]. However, as yet, little is known on the catalytic implications of the spatial metal distribution on the nanometer scale, and how this parameter can be controlled. In recent years, fundamental studies based on the combination of 3D model catalysts and advanced electron microscopy methods, for example, electron tomography [87], have added significantly to the current level of understanding. Particularly when regular mesostructures are employed as catalyst support, interpretation of microscopy results is facilitated and even quantitative descriptors for the metal nanoscale distribution can be derived [88]. In addition, the advent of aberration corrected microscopy methods has made it possible to determine the 3D location of low-atomicity metal clusters [89], or even single metal atoms confined within porous matrices [90]. Using TEM on microtomed thin sections as a diagnostic tool, Lu et al. [91] reported the spatially controlled incorporation of iron oxide nanoparticles within an ordered mesoporous carbon with a bimodal pore system, via a cooperative design of metal loading and support nanocasting synthesis steps. Similarly, with the assistance of electron tomography to assess the location of metal nanoparticles in 3D, synthetic strategies have been developed to selectively deposit metal nanoparticles either inside or on the outer surface of carbon nanotubes [92,93]. For catalysts prepared via aqueous impregnation of porous oxide carriers, which is a route of high relevance for the manufacture of industrial catalysts, it has been shown that formation of high-metal-density domains or clusters of nanoparticles, can be controlled, or eventually prevented, through the choice of solvent or the addition of organic additives during the impregnation step [94,95]. In a recent study, Eggenhuisen et al. [96] employed cryo-electron tomography to track the distribution of the metal (Ni and Co) nitrate precursors within the pores of an ordered silica mesostructure throughout different stages of catalyst synthesis and activation. The drying step following impregnation was identified as particularly influential for the ultimate metal distribution, and freeze-drying was proposed as an efficient approach to prevent metal redistribution and clustering. For nitrate-derived catalysts, the gas composition and gas–solid hydrodynamics during the subsequent thermal decomposition treatments (calcination) have also been found to have a remarkable influence on the ultimate spatial distribution of the supported metal nanoparticles [97,98]. The increasing degree of control over the distribution of the supported species on porous carriers, together with the possibility to test 3D model catalysts under relevant reaction conditions, is currently a source of valuable knowledge on the catalytic consequences of the metal spatial distribution. As an example, notably different activity and selectivity have been reported for metal nanoparticles either supported on the external surface or confined to the interior of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [99,100]. Such differences have been attributed to electronic effects, related to the electron-deficient inner side of the CNTs [100], or the local concentration of reactants in the confined spaced [99]. Next to “initial” performance, metal spatial distribution can also be crucial for the catalyst lifetime. Working with CuZn/SiO2 model catalysts, Prieto et al. [101,102] found that maximizing the Cu interparticle spacing slowed down notably catalyst deactivation under methanol synthesis conditions (Fig. 10 ). This was ascribed to the contribution of Cu particle migration and coalescence to an accelerated metal growth, and thereby catalyst deactivation, when the metal nanoparticles were in close proximity in the as-activated catalyst. In contrast, Munnik et al. [103] concluded that interparticle spacing is not a decisive parameter for the growth of Ni nanoparticles under CO methanation conditions. This observation pointed to an Ostwald ripening process based on a fast gas phase exchange of Ni(CO)4 species between static metal nanoparticles as the dominant growth pathway, which renders the distance between individual metal nanoparticles inconsequential for the growth rate. These studies exemplify how model supported catalysts, with controlled mesoscale features, can serve to gain understanding on not only the preferred catalyst structure for an optimal performance, but also on the mechanisms of catalyst degradation under industrially relevant operation conditions. In addition to the supported metal species, fine tuning of the support porosity in 3D model systems offers the possibility to investigate a number of aspects of significance for catalyst synthesis and usage. The use of ordered silica mesostructures as carriers has been instrumental to reveal the impact of pore size [104], morphology [105], and connectivity [101,106] on the stability of the supported metal nanoparticles against agglomeration and growth. Analogous studies revealed the influence of the pore dimension on diffusion phenomena during catalyst operation [107,108]. In recent years, high-resolution spectroscopic methods have reached the spatiotemporal resolution required to detect single turnover events, at the nanoscale, during the catalytic action of porous catalysts [84,109]. Coupling of these imaging techniques with deliberate morphological control of ordered mesoporous supports or catalysts, for example, by tuning pore size and length [110,111], is anticipated to help in elucidating the relative kinetic relevance of intra-pore mass transport and surface reaction phenomena, and thereby guide the design of more efficient catalysts. Finally, yet another important sub-class of 3D model catalysts is based on morphologically designed, non-porous oxides. As implied from extensive surface science investigations on single-crystals, the physico-chemical properties, the nature and density of certain surface defects, for example, oxygen vacancies, and the catalytic properties of most metals and metal oxides varies significantly as a function of the surface-exposed crystallographic facet. Particularly over the last two decades, significant progress in the synthesis of nanostructures has enabled the preparation of metal oxides with unprecedented control over not only the crystal size but also the crystal shape. Such morphological control opened up new possibilities to select those crystallographic facets (predominantly) exposed on the surface of oxide nanomaterials, which has in turn been exploited to investigate surface structure sensitivity effects in catalysis [112]. Zhou et al. [113] first reported that CeO2 nanorods, exposing preferentially {001} and {110} facets, showed a substantially higher surface-specific activity for CO oxidation than CeO2 nanocrystals of irregular shapes, for which the majority of the surface facets corresponded to more compact {111} planes. More recently, Laursen et al. found CeO2 octahedra nanocrystals terminated by {111} facets to exhibit the highest activity and selectivity toward the desired dicarbamoylated products in the carbamoylation of aromatic amines with dimethyl carbonate, a reaction which is crucial in potential “greener,” phosgene-free processes to produce polyurethanes [114]. Given that many oxides play a non-innocent role when applied as support material in metal catalysts, similar facet-dependent catalytic properties have been revealed for metal nanoparticles deposited on morphologically tailored oxide supports. For instance, Si and Flytzani-Stephanopoulos [115] discovered that Au nanoparticles show the highest activity for the water–gas shift reaction when supported on CeO2 nanorods, which expose preferentially {110} facets, as compared to alternative support crystal shapes (Fig. 11 ). Later, analogous oxide shape effects have been reported for a number of other metal catalyzed reactions [112,116]. In some instances, the operation conditions applied in the large-scale manufacture of high surface area oxide materials can be adjusted to favor specific crystal growth behaviors, thereby permitting certain control over the ultimate crystal shape. Hence, the information gathered with model systems with well-defined support morphologies is of interest to design advanced catalysts of potential industrial relevance. 4 Concluding remarks There are not many industrial catalysis researchers who have contributed to various parts of both catalysis science and catalysis technology in a similarly broad manner as Haldor Topsøe – on top of founding a successful international company. In this contribution, we have tried to capture his influence on the art – and he was partly responsible for converting it more to a science – of catalyst synthesis. With the other contributions in this special issue, it emerges the picture of a truly outstanding scientist with broad impact in the whole field of catalysis. And Haldor Topsøe did this not alone through his personal work, but also through the kind of organization and set of values he established in his company, and by which he influenced generations of catalysis researchers. His broad view of catalysis is probably best captured in his own words: “We thought that catalysis would offer us everything we wanted, offer us a possibility to use our more scientific interest, offer us possibilities to manufacture catalysts through engineering and develop processes and thus earn sufficient money to justify our work with more theoretical scientific problems” [4]. In particular, Topsøe advocated resolutely the application of model, simplified materials to deconvolute the complexity of technical catalysts and investigate fundamental aspects in a systematic manner. The knowledge arising from studies on model systems proved, in several instances, highly valuable to rationalize how performance relates to catalyst genesis, and paved the way to the development of industrial catalysts for various processes. Such “reductionism” approach continues to deliver unprecedented insights into fundamental aspects which are central to solid catalyst design and preparation, with notable contributions from several scientists to extend its scope as well as to bridge the gaps between model systems and technical catalysts. coredata.dc:description: When Haldor Topsøe founded his company in 1940, the application of solid catalysts in industrial chemical processes was still in its early phase. At that time, catalyst development and optimization strongly relied on phenomenological approaches and experimental know-how, whereas little knowledge existed on the nature of the catalytically active species and how to tune their structure and concentration. For more than 70years, Topsøe has advocated the need of “bringing more scientific understanding to the field of catalysis,” becoming a prominent figure in the transition of catalyst preparation – a word with an alchemical connotation – to catalyst synthesis, based on scientific principles. Numerous fundamental studies of his team and collaborators on simplified model catalysts have added substantially to the current understanding of a significant number of industrially relevant systems in particular, and the principles of action of solid catalysts in general. This article reviews some key advancements that the Topsøe team has contributed to the field of catalyst development, rooted in fundamental studies with either 2D or 3D model materials. Examples are provided of how the acquired scientific knowledge was successfully translated into innovations in the manufacture of technical catalysts. Next to the work of the Topsøe group, a broader and updated perspective of the use of model systems to investigate fundamental aspects of catalyst development is presented. A number of selected case studies are reviewed, which we find illustrative of recent findings with implications for the design and synthesis of solid catalysts.
